text:
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comma with thumbprint cookies that's

right I am very excited to be sharing
grandma's amazing thumbprint cookie

recipe and for the record not my grandma
a complete strangers grandma whose

identity will be revealed in the blog
post but anyway using her incredible and

easy to make dough we're actually gonna
do two versions of these cookies only

one of which require thumbs to make so
with that let's go ahead and get started

with this very simple dough it will
begin by adding some powdered sugar to

some room temperature butter and we'll
take a spatula and cream this all

together and this dough is so simple and
basic we don't even need any electric

mixers or any mechanical assistance of
any kind

okay we're simply gonna spatulate that
butter and powdered sugar until it

creams together at which point we're
gonna stop and add a few more

ingredients including some vanilla
extract the pure and the real please as

well as a little touch of almond extract
which is technically optional but I

enjoy it
we will also toss in a pinch of salt as

well as one large egg yolk which should
not be confused here with a whole egg

okay we just want the yolk and then
we'll take our spatula and give that a

mix and right about here the people that
would insist on an electric mixer for

this are gonna say that by using just a
spatula here we're not gonna be able to

perfectly emulsify all those ingredients
together which is absolutely true or if

you use a machine this is gonna look a
lot smoother and creamier and it won't

have that kind of broken grainy ish
appearance like this one does but it

does not matter because when we stop and
add the flour and continue to mix this

everything's gonna get incorporated
perfectly and we're gonna end up with

the exact same final product is that
people that pulled out the electric

mixer so go ahead and use the machinery
if you want I mean in this production

you are the helen mirren of whether
you're smearing but to me there's no

advantage and you're gonna have more to
clean up so I'm gonna blend this with

nothing more than a spatula until all
the flowers incorporated and don't worry

you really can't over mix this dough so
if you mix it further once the flours

incorporated it doesn't really cause a
problem but the point is why would you

keep on mixing once something's mixed
that's kind of crazy

so as soon as we have everything mixed
together we'll stop and we will move on

to form our cookies
which I like to portion out using this

little survey scoop because one rounded
scoops going to give me exactly a half

an ounce
also known as one tablespoon and as we

scoop these what we'll do is transfer
those onto a plate of white sugar and

roll that around until it's covered
at which point we'll roll that between

our palms to form a beautifully smooth
ball which we will then place on a

Silpat lined baking sheet and in
addition to making the outside of the

cookie look better and have a better
texture that sugar is also going to

prevent it from sticking to your palms
as you roll this and by the way one of

the secrets to perfect uncracked
thumbprint cookies is not refrigerating

the dough okay we really do want to work
with that at room temperature so it's

nice and soft and then once we have
those panned up one more tip for

avoiding cracks is before we make the
well in the center of each one we want

to give those a little initial pressing
with our fingers all right not too much

we'll just flatten those out a little
bit before we move on to final

fabrication and there's basically two
ways you can go here one is a shortbread

cookie featuring some jam which is the
one we're gonna do first and the others

a jam cookie featuring some shortbread
and for this first one instead of using

our thumb I'm actually gonna use the
bottom of this freakishly large wooden

spoon that I've lightly dusted with a
powdered sugar and we'll press that

straight down in but not all the way to
the bottom okay we want to stop about an

eighth of an inch short and by poking
straight down with this spoon versus our

thumb we're gonna get a smaller sharper
indentation it's gonna give these more

of what I call a bakery look oh and by
the way if you don't have a thick spoon

like this you could just use one of your
smaller NAM thumb fingers and then once

all our dough balls have been handled
we'll go ahead and fill those with

whatever jam we want and right here I'm
using one made for marionberry which I

believe is the only berry named after a
former us mirror so just a little bit of

trivia for you and then once we have
those filled I do like to give them the

old habit ABBA to kind of settle
everything down at which point these are

ready to transfer into the center of a
325 degree oven for 15 minutes or until

they are not golden brown alright
because with these cookies were choosing

taste and texture over appearance so
these really are going to be quite light

and barely blonde when they come out but
don't worry they are cooked and unlike

the tops about
we'll be golden brown and then what

we'll do is very carefully transfer
those onto a cooling rack and let them

cool completely before we try to ice
them otherwise that--how jam will kind

of melt the icing and it won't look as
good so I let those sit for about 20

minutes before I grab my pastry bag in a
fine tip and piped over a very basic

icing which of course I will give you
the recipe for it's just powdered sugar

and water and I'm gonna do four lines
one way and for the other it'd be

careful not to move your piping tip too
fast okay watch the center of this one

because I did that too quick and that
line of icing was not thick enough it

kind of spread apart and now I have a
hole in the middle which I might go back

and fix later I'm not sure it depends on
my mood but anyway the point is go nice

and slow and steady so you have a nice
even flow and of course like anything

the more you do the better you'll get
and then once we have those iced what we

want to do is let them sit for about 15
or 20 minutes so that that icing sort of

hardens up so I let those sit for a
little bit before plating them up and I

promptly went in for a taste and people
like to throw the term

melt-in-your-mouth around but these
truly were melt in your mouth I mean the

texture is so tender and buttery
it's a miracle these things stay

together and of course we have that
beautiful gooey jammy Center so there's

no mystery why this is such an iconic
cookie especially around the holidays

okay so that was version 1 basically a
shortbread cookie with a little bit of

jam now let me show you version 2 which
is much more Jam forward and these get

prepped and panned up exactly the same
way except instead of pressing down with

a wooden spoon or dowel
we're gonna use an actual human thumb

which as you can see is going to give us
a significantly larger and more shallow

depression into which we're gonna be
able to spoon like twice as much jam and

this time I'm going with strawberry in
case it matters to you the redder

berries like strawberry raspberry etc do
probably make for a better looking

cookie or at least more colorful and
that's it once those are filled we'll

give them the old hole tap a tab but
just like the first batch and we will

again pop those into the center of our
325 oven for 15 minutes or until again

they're not quite golden brown and then
the only difference post baking with

these because they are pressed out a
little thin

and have more Jam they are much more
fragile when they're warm so we should

probably let those sit down the panic
for at least five minutes

so they firm up a little bit before we
try to transfer them onto a cooling rack

and since we did the fancy icing on the
first batch we'll just go ahead and use

some powdered sugar on these and what's
gonna happen after you dust that over is

that the powdered sugar on the jam is
gonna dissolve and disappear but the

sugar that's on the cookie part is gonna
stay which once plated up makes for a

very simple but beautiful presentation
and of course to be fair and consistent

I'll go ahead and taste one of these as
well but unfortunately as I pick that

one up I dropped it on the table and it
broke so I had to grab another one

but anyway even though these were made
with the same dough using basically the

same technique this style does give you
a different experience all right it's

definitely jammy ER but because it's
also thinner these seemed even more

tender and melt in your mouth oh by the
way one tip for you kids watching don't

be putting your cookie back on the
serving platter after every bite okay

that's not good table manners you're
only allowed to do that kind of stuff

here for film in a recipe video but
anyway that's it how to make thumbprint

cookies two slightly different styles
and which one did I like better it was a

tie they were both perfect in their own
way and for a variety sake you should

probably do some of each but whether you
do both or just one or the other I

really do hope you give these a try soon
so head over to food wishes calm for all

the ingredient amounts of Morpho as
usual and as always enjoy
you
